clinicalDescription: Overview: Cough is commonly classified by duration with acute cough lasting < 3 weeks, sub-acute (3 to 8 weeks), chronic (> 8 weeks). Cough is the result of irritation to cough receptors that are triggered by chemical/mechanical stimuli and are present in many areas in the body including pericardium, diaphragm, stomach.Presentation: Cough is a common manifestation of several conditions. Acute cough may be a symptom of an infection, while the chronic cough may be because of gastroesophageal reflux disease, asthma, drugs like ACE inhibitors, chronic bronchitis, eosinophilc bronchitis, lung cancer, smoking etc. Assessment: History is most important for diagnosis to understand the duration and inciting factors of the cough. Assessment: depends on the underlying suspected cause.Plan: Specific treatment is to identify and treat the underlying disease. Non specific treatment includes centrally acting antitussive agents like dextromethorphan, codeine, morphine.Prognosis: Good, if eliciting agent may be identified and eliminated.
